title: 'Operation India': Racism row over council's choice of name of exercise to crackdown on dodgy taxi drivers - Mirror Online
text:

A council is being slammed for choosing the title 'Operation India' as a name for it crackdown on dodgy taxi drivers. 
Amid accusations of racism , critics claim it's a "shocking" choice of name - but the authority in Milton Keynes response is that it is simply an innocent coincidence. 
It said it was following convention by using the international phonetic alphabet - as the previous operations were called Foxtrot, Golf and Hotel. 
Operation India was set up as a joint initiative between the council's cab licensing officers and Thames Valley Police to carry out checks on taxi drivers. 
But a cab boss who has worked in Milton Keynes for 12 years said: "I think it will cause outrage across the taxi driving community." 
The man, who asked not to be named, added: "Just to use the word... it’s like they’re implying criminal drivers are Indian. 
"Why did they have to use a country or race? 
"I don’t have a problem with the police and council coming to check that our taxis are legal and safe. 
"However to use 'India' as the name of the operation is racially insensitive and it should be retracted." 
Milton Keynes councillor Mohammed Khan said: "It’s essentially blaming all Indian taxi drivers... these are good hard-working people who work unsocial hours to make sure people get home safely. 
"This name must be reconsidered - people will be outraged and it does not send a good message about ethnic minorities." Councillor Mohammed Khan said the name's "essentially blaming all Indian taxi drivers" 
Navrita Atwal, chief executive of the Milton Keynes Equality Council, said "Anything giving preconceived messages where communities are being policed should be avoided. 
"We would always encourage using names for project that build and create good community relations. 
"We are living in sensitive times and should exercise double cautious as to not cause offence or mistrust as community relations take a long time to build." Read More 
However a council spokeswoman said: "These joint operations are identified using the internationally recognised phonetic alphabet - for example the previous three operations were called Operation Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel. 
"It is very common practice and the next operation will be called Operation Juliet. 
"These operations are important in helping to ensure that the public can be guaranteed a safe journey in a roadworthy vehicle and we will continue to carry them out." The council in Milton Keynes said it was just a coincidence Read More Read pervert taxi driver's creepy messages about passenger's daughter after adding her on Facebook 
The scheme, which targets Hackey Carriage and Private Hire vehicles with suspected defects or breaches, saw 12 licensed vehicles stopped in just one day (January 27). 
Of the 12 vehicles stopped, nine were identified as having suspected or confirmed defects and were suspended and sent for inspection. 
To prevent a recurrence of defective vehicles, the swoop team will take further action against taxi proprietors and operators in accordance with the council’s taxi policy. Like us on Facebook
